Term.Name: INFORM
INFORMER
Term.Definition: Programme intended primarily to inform about current facts, situations, events, theories or forecasts, or to provide explanatory background information and advice. Information programme content has to be non-durable, that is to say that one could not imagine that the same programme would be transmitted e.g. one year later without losing most of its relevance. Examples: news, documentaries about current subjects, consumer information

Term.Name: Infotainment
Information + divertissement
Term.Definition: Programmes intended primarily to inform but with entertaining elements.

Term.Name: Advice
Conseil
Term.Definition: Programme intended to advise about matters of personal interest such as consumer prices and quality, financial matters, health, or, for the interest of special groups, weather or traffic information

Term.Name: ENRICH
INSTRUIRE
Term.Definition: Programme primarily intended to increase knowledge about non-current subjects in a didactic or non-didactic way, or to religiously inspire. Enrichment programme content has to be durable, that is to say, one could very well imagine that the programme would be broadcast one year later, without loosing its relevance. Examples: travelogues, war documentaries, educational programmes, religious programmes .

Term.Name: Education
Éducation
Term.Definition: Programme primarily intended to increase knowledge about non current subjects in a non-didactic way.

Term.Name: General enrichment
Instruction (général)
Term.Definition: Programme primarily intended to increase knowledge about non current subjects in a non-didactic way.

Term.Name: Inspirational enrichment
Instruction (inspiration)
Term.Definition: Programme based on different forms of religious beliefs or intended to edify the audience.

Term.Name: ENTERTAIN
AMUSER
Term.Definition: Programme intended primarily to evoke relaxation, feelings of pleasure and/or awareness of beauty.

Term.Name: Informative entertainment
Variétés informatives
Term.Definition: Programmes intended primarily to entertain but with informative elements.

Term.Name: PROMOTE
PROMOUVOIR
Term.Definition: Intended to promote content. Produced by the broadcaster or media owner. eg trails for TV/Radio

Term.Name: ADVERTISE
FAIRE DE LA PUBLICITÉ
Term.Definition: Intended to inform consumers about commercial products and services. Produced by/on behalf the owners/sellers of the product or service eg Interstitial commercials

Term.Name: FORMAT
FORMAT
Term.Definition: For use where proprietary extensions are required, or the use of keywords that do not fit in any classification below

Term.Name: STRUCTURED / NON-FICTION
STRUCTURE / NON-FICTION
Term.Definition: All programmes dealing with facts, situations, opinions, theories and forecasts

Term.Name: Bulletin
Bulletin
Term.Definition: Programme with formal desk presentation, usually interspersed with visual material.Example: news bulletin, weather forecast

Term.Name: Magazine
Magazine
Term.Definition: Programme consisting of separate items which has at least one common quality and presented under one main heading

Term.Name: Commented event
Événement commenté
Term.Definition: An outside event covered by the broadcaster and with an accompanying commentary, and transmitted live or deferred (within 2. hours).

Term.Name: Documentary
Documentaire
Term.Definition: Programme concerning a single theme, involving descriptive and/or interpretative commentaries, illustrations, I/vs, statements, photos etc

Term.Name: Discussion/Interview/Debate/Talkshow
Discussion/Talk show/Interview/Débat
Term.Definition: Mainly verbal programme in which more than one person participates

Term.Name: Lecture/Speech/Presentation
Lecture/Discours/ Présentation
Term.Definition: Mainly verbal programme in which only one person participates

Term.Name: Textual (incl. relayed teletext)
Textuel (y compris le télétexte relayé)
Term.Definition: Programme consisting only of alphanumerical information

Term.Name: Phone-in
Tribune téléphonique
Term.Definition: Programme with content primarily generated by contributions from the general audience either on the telephone or by sending in emails/letters

Term.Name: DJ with discs
DJ avec disques
Term.Definition: Programme (usually in audio only) in which a specialist presenter introduces music or other pre-recorded elements

Term.Name: Simple game show
Jeu télévisé / Quiz
Term.Definition: Programme in which the content is primarily contained within the studio and the prizes or rewards (if any) to the participant(s) may be regarded as conservative. Example: University Challenge

Term.Name: Big game show
Jeu télévisé / Compétition
Term.Definition: Programme produced on a grand scale in which the prizes or rewards are considered generous Example: Who wants to be a millionaire

Term.Name: Standup comedian(s)
One man show / Standup
Term.Definition: Programme performed by a single, a pair or a group of comedians performing directly towards the audience

Term.Name: Hosted show
Émission animée
Term.Definition: Programme, that can be regarded neither as non-fiction nor as drama or music/dance in which one or more persons fulfil the role of presenter, host, quiz or games master, announcer, chairperson or speaker and where the rest of the participants are generally members of the public

Term.Name: Panel-show
Émission avec panel
Term.Definition: A programme of a light entertainment nature which is presented by a more or less fixed group of people (panel). Programme, that can be regarded neither as non-fiction nor as drama or concert. Example: The Paul Daniels Show; Der Rudi Carrell Show

Term.Name: REPRESENTATION/PLAY/FICTION
REPRÉSENTATION / PIÈCE /FICTION
Term.Definition: Programme consisting of a prose or verse composition, one telling a story, written for or as if for performance by actors.Examples: soap opera, Shakespeare play, Monthy Python, radio play, Not: documentary or informational programme whose subject is drama

Term.Name: Fictional portrayal of life / Performance Drama
Term.Definition: Programme performed by live actors e.g. Performed drama

Term.Name: Readings
Lectures
Term.Definition: Programmes consisting of readings of poems, stories or other literary works

Term.Name: ARTISTIC PERFORMANCE
PERFORMANCE ARTISTIQUE
Term.Definition: Music, Dance, Mime etc. TV programmes (predominantly) consisting of music, dance or ballet or theatrical performance

Term.Name: Solo performance
Performance en soliste
Term.Definition: individual performance of music, dance, mime or spoken word eg Nigel Kennedy solo violin performance

Term.Name: Small ensemble performance
Performance de petit ensemble
Term.Definition: Performance of music, dance, mime or spoken word by a small number of people Quartet, small ensemble staged play

Term.Name: Large ensemble performance
Performance de grand ensemble
Term.Definition: Performance of music, dance, mime or spoken word by a large number of people Orchestra and choirs

Term.Name: INTERACTIVE
INTERACTIVE
Term.Definition: Formats making use of a range of features such as local application support, return path and direct viewer interaction

Term.Name: LOCAL INTERACTIVITY
Interactivité locale
Term.Definition: Formats that happen in the "box" where broadcast "data" is processed locally giving a sense of dynamic choice

Term.Name: INTERMITTENT RESPONSE
Réponse intermittente
Term.Definition: Formats that require an intermittent or continuous return path

Term.Name: ALWAYS ON CONNECTION
Toujours connecté
Term.Definition: Formats that ideally require a continuous connection to be delivered

Term.Name: News
Actualités
Term.Definition: Time-sensitive information

Term.Name: Sports
Sports
Term.Definition: news of sporting events NB not to be used for regular sporting coverage

Term.Name: Consumer affairs
Protection des consommateurs
Term.Definition: e.g. Watchdog

Term.Name: Economy/Market/Financial/Business
Économie / Marché / Finances / Affaires
Term.Definition: e.g. financial news programme from stock market

Term.Name: Religion
Religion
Term.Reference: See ETSI TS 102 822-3-1 (www.etsi.org) for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: Non-religious philosophies
Philosophies non religieuses
Term.Reference: See ETSI TS 102 822-3-1 (www.etsi.org) for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: Humanities
Lettres
Term.Definition: The branches of learning regarded as having primarily a cultural character and which usually include language, literature, history, mathematics and philosophy

Term.Name: Events
Événements
Term.Definition: Coverage of events, not the event itself (see format)

Term.Name: Field
Sauts et lancers
Term.Reference: See www.olympic.org for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: Track
Course à pied
Term.Reference: See www.olympic.org for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: Indoor cycling / Track
Cyclisme sur piste
Term.Reference: See www.olympic.org for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: Road cycling
Cyclisme sur route
Term.Reference: See www.olympic.org for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: Camogie
Camogie
Term.Definition: Female version of Hurling.

Term.Name: Shinty
Shinty
Term.Definition: Scottish game, also known as Camanachd.

Term.Name: Swimming
Natation
Term.Reference: See www.olympic.org for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: Synchronised swimming
Natation synchronisée
Term.Reference: See www.olympic.org for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: Diving
Plongeon
Term.Reference: See www.olympic.org for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: Figure skating
Patinage artistique
Term.Reference: See www.olympic.org for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: Short-track skating
Patinage de vitesse sur piste courte
Term.Reference: See www.olympic.org for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: Speed skating
Patinage de vitesse
Term.Reference: See www.olympic.org for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: Snowboarding
Surf des neiges
Term.Reference: See www.olympic.org for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: Alpine skiing
Ski alpin
Term.Reference: See www.olympic.org for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: Freestyle skiing
Ski acrobatique
Term.Reference: See www.olympic.org for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: Nordic skiing
Ski nordique
Term.Reference: See www.olympic.org for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: Ski jumping
Saut à ski
Term.Reference: See www.olympic.org for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: Biathlon
Biathlon
Term.Reference: See www.olympic.org for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: Nordic combined
Combiné nordique
Term.Reference: See www.olympic.org for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: Auto racing
Courses de voitures
Term.Definition: Motor car racing not covered elsewhere - eg Formula Ford, Formula .000, V8 championship etc

Term.Name: Motor cycling
Courses de motos
Term.Definition: Speedway, TT etc

Term.Name: Motor boating
Courses de bateaux é moteur
Term.Definition: Motor racing on water!

Term.Name: Trotting
Trot
Term.Definition: Horse with two wheel cart and a jockey

Term.Name: Mountain sports other than winter sports
Sports de montagne autres que les sports d'hiver
Shooting
Tir
Term.Reference: See www.olympics.orf for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: Combative / Contact sports other than martial arts
Sports de combat / de contact autres que les arts martiaux
Term.Definition: Other than martial arts

Term.Name: Air sports
Sports aéronautiques
Term.Definition: Programme consisting of elements on aviation as sport. Elements concerning commercial aviation should be categorized in Air Transport (3.1.8.1) and elements concerning private pilots and general aviation should go in Leisure/Hobbies, aviation (3.3.34)

Term.Name: Gliding
Vol libre
Term.Definition: Airplane without engine

Term.Name: Plane
Avion
Term.Definition: Airplane with engine(s)

Term.Name: Mind Games
Jeux de concentration
Term.Definition: Competetive tests of mental acuity. This category should only be used where the coverage relates to the competetivemness of the event. It is not intended for use where the coverage is intended for education purposes

Term.Name: Traditional Games
Jeux traditionnels
Term.Definition: Intended for local use for specific traditional national games

Term.Name: FICTION/DRAMA
FICTION
Term.Definition: Programme consisting of a prose or verse composition, resp. one telling a story, written for or as if for performance by actors, puppets or animated

Term.Name: General light / Popular drama
Fiction populaire générale
Term.Definition: Drama written after approximately 1918 and without literary or cultural pretensions. Popular drama, e.g. Upstairs, Downstairs

Term.Name: Soap
Soap
Term.Definition: Dramatized serial programme dealing with easy-to-grasp situations performed by a limited cast

Term.Name: Romance / Melodrama
Romance / mélodrame
Term.Definition: e.g. Romeo and Juliet

Term.Name: Fantasy / Fairy tale
Film fantastique/conte de fées
Term.Definition: EG Alice in Wonderland

Term.Name: Adult drama /Erotica
Fiction pour adultes / érotique
Term.Definition: E.g. Emannuelle

Term.Name: Drama based on real events (docudrama)
Documentaire dramatisé (docufiction)
Term.Definition: Drama based upon reality sometimes with documentary inserts

Term.Name: Classical drama
Fiction classique
Term.Definition: Drama written before approximately 1918 e.g. Hamlet, Othello

Term.Name: Religious
Religieux
Term.Definition: e.g. The Red Robe,

Term.Name: Biographical drama
Fiction biographique
Term.Definition: e.g. Young Winston,

Term.Name: Quiz / Contest
Quiz / concours
Term.Definition: Competitions calling into play the competitors' special knowledge and intelligence

Term.Name: Quiz
Quiz
Term.Definition: Who Wants to be a millionaire - questions and answers form the entertainment

Term.Name: Contest
Concours
Term.Definition: Participants compete directly with each other eg Americas Top Model, Generation Game

Term.Name: Variety/Talent
Variétés/nouveaux talents
Term.Definition: Programme with various performers such as comedians, magicians, singers etc. e.g. Paul Daniels Show, Relay from a circus

Term.Name: Cabaret
Cabaret
Term.Definition: Specific instance of Variety in an intimate environment

Term.Name: Talent
Term.Definition: Spelling Bees, singing talent shows - Stars in their eyes, American Idol

Term.Name: Chat
Discussion
Term.Definition: Chat Show in which a presenter interviews a celebrity

Term.Name: Broken comedy
Comédie par sketches
Term.Definition: Humorous and/or satirical programme consisting of short dramatical sequences, sketches, performed by comedians e,g, Benny Hill, Monty Python

Term.Name: Satire
Satire
Term.Definition: Letterman, Dave Allen, etc.

Term.Name: Humour
Humour
Term.Definition: Programme without sketches or �roken drama� consisting (mainly) of verbal jokes, gags, bloopers etc.

Term.Name: Surprise
Surprise
Term.Definition: Programme of 'dream comes true' type e.g. Jim'llFix It

Term.Name: Classical music
Musique classique
Term.Definition: Music including chamber, instrumental, operatic, symphonic, vocal and choral music

Term.Name: Early
Ancienne
Term.Definition: Music written before the middle of the 17th Century

Term.Name: Classical
Classique
Term.Definition: Music from the middle of the 18th until the end of the 19th Century

Term.Name: Contemporary
Contemporaine
Term.Definition: Music from the 20th Century onwards

Term.Name: Light classical
Classique légère
Term.Definition: Music by Strauss, Lehar, etc.

Term.Name: Opera
Opéra ["*]
Term.Definition: e.g. La Boheme

Term.Name: Solo instruments
Instruments solistes (ex : piano)
Term.Definition: (e.g. Piano)

Term.Name: Chamber
Chambre
Term.Definition: Small group of instruments

Term.Name: Symphonic
Symphonique
Term.Definition: Large group of instruments

Term.Name: Vocal
Vocale
Term.Definition: Solo or individual singing

Term.Name: Choral
Chorale
Term.Definition: Group of singers

Term.Name: Experimental/Avant Garde
Expérimentale /Avant-garde
Term.Definition: e.g. John Cage

Term.Name: Jazz
Jazz
Term.Definition: Indigenous American popular music, born in New Orleans of African slaves social circumstances. The jazz idiom is characterized by certain syncopations over strongly reiterated rhythms in which improvisation plays an important part

Term.Name: Big band/Swing/Dixie
Big band/Swing/Dixie
Term.Definition: e.g. Glenn Miller, Chris Barber

Term.Name: Blues/Soul jazz
Blues/soul jazz
Term.Definition: e.g. L. Armstrong

Term.Name: Bop/Hard bop/Bebop/Postbop
Bop/Bebop/Hardbop /Postbop
Term.Definition: e.g. Sonny Rollings, Oscar Peterson, J. Coltrane, T. Monk

Term.Name: Latin and World jazz
Latin & World jazz
Term.Definition: e.g. Manu Dibango

Term.Name: Acid jazz/Fusion
Acid jazz / fusion
Term.Definition: e.g. G. Benson, Miles Davis

Term.Name: Cool
Cool
Term.Definition: e.g. Modern Jazz Quartet

Term.Name: Pop-rock
Pop-rock
Term.Definition: The most central and widely circulated types of popular music, in particular rock and roll, etc

Term.Name: Pop
Pop
Term.Definition: e.g. early Beatles

Term.Name: Chanson/Ballad
Chanson/ballade
Term.Definition: e.g. Juliette Gr�co, Leonard Cohen

Term.Name: Traditional rock and roll
Rock and roll traditionnel
Term.Definition: e.g. Elvis Presley

Term.Name: Classic/Dance/Pop-rock
Classique/dance/pop-rock
Term.Definition: e.g. Michael Jackson, Spice Girls, Johnny Halliday, Rolling Stones

Term.Name: Folk
Folk
Term.Definition: e.g. Bob Dylan

Term.Name: Seasonal/Holiday
Musiques de Noël
Term.Definition: e.g. Christmas

Term.Name: Karaoke/Singing contests
Karaoke / concours de chant
Term.Definition: e.g. Pizzicato Five

Term.Name: AOR / Slow Rock / Soft Rock
AOR/Slow Rock/Soft Rock
Term.Definition: Adult-Orientated Rock e.g. The Eagles.

Term.Name: Metal
Métal
Term.Definition: e.g. Iron Maiden

Term.Name: Glam Rock
Glam Rock
Term.Definition: e.g. T-Rex

Term.Name: Punk Rock
Rock punk
Term.Definition: e.g. The Sex Pistols

Term.Name: Prog / Symphonic Rock
Rock symphonique / prog
Term.Definition: e.g. Yes

Term.Name: Experimental / Avant Garde
Expérimental / Avant-garde
Term.Definition: e.g. Coil

Term.Name: Art Rock
Art Rock
Term.Definition: e.g. Talking Heads

Term.Name: Folk Rock
Folk Rock
Term.Definition: e.g. The Byrds

Term.Name: Nu Punk
Nu Punk
Term.Definition: e.g. Rancid

Term.Name: Grunge
Grunge
Term.Definition: e.g. Nirvana

Term.Name: Garage Punk/Psychedelia
Garage Punk / Psychedelia
Term.Definition: 1960s. e.g. The Sonics

Term.Name: Heavy Rock
Heavy Rock
Term.Definition: e.g. Led Zeppelin, Cream, Hendrix

Term.Name: New Wave
New Wave
Term.Definition: e.g. Blondie

Term.Name: Easy listening / Exotica
Musique d'ambiance / Exotique
Term.Definition: e.g. Yma Sumac

Term.Name: Singer/Songwriter
Chanteur/ Auteur-compositeur
Term.Definition: e.g. Paul Simon, James Taylor

Term.Name: Blues / Rhythm and Blues / Soul / Gospel / Spiritual
Blues/Rhythm and blues/Soul/Gospel/Spiritual
R & B
R & B
Term.Definition: 1990s RandB (e.g. Teddy Riley) not 1960s Rhythm and Blues (e.g. The Rolling Stones).

Term.Name: Rhythm and Blues
Rhythm and Blues
Term.Definition: 1960s RandB (eg. The Rolling Stones) not 1990s RandB (eg. Teddy Riley).

Term.Name: Funk
Funk
Term.Definition: e.g. James Brown

Term.Name: Garage (1990s)
Garage (1990s)
Term.Definition: 1990s US Garage not 1960s Garage Punk.

Term.Name: Breakbeat
Breakbeat
Term.Definition: e.g. Fatboy Slim

Term.Name: Ambient Dance
Ambient Dance
Term.Definition: e.g. The Orb

Term.Name: Alternative Dance
Alternative Dance
Term.Definition: e.g. Moby

Term.Name: World/Traditional/Ethnic/Folk music
Musiques du monde/Traditionnel/Ethnique/Folk
Term.Definition: Music that is the product of a tradition that has been evolved through the process of oral transmission

Term.Name: INTERACTIVE GAMES
JEUX INTERACTIFS
Term.Reference: See ETSI TS 102 822-3-1 (www.etsi.org) for more detailed categorisation

Term.Name: INTENDED AUDIENCE
public visé / groupe cible
Term.Definition: Programmes not intended for a specific target group.

Term.Name: GENERAL AUDIENCE
GRAND PUBLIC
Term.Definition: Programmes not intended for a specific target group.

Term.Name: AGE GROUPS
GROUPES D'AGE
Term.Definition: The age group levels for which the programme is primarily intended..

Term.Name: Ethnic
Ethnique
Term.Definition: Programme for people differing in language and/or culture E.g. .Local key words to apply (ie Asian, )

Term.Name: Religious
Religieux
Term.Definition: Local key words to apply (ie Shinto, Christian, Hindu etc)

Term.Name: OCCUPATIONAL GROUPS
CATÉGORIES PROFESSIONNELLES
Term.Definition: The occupation of the consumer for whitch the programme is primarely intended

Term.Name: OTHER
AUTRES
Term.Definition: Local Keywords to apply. (ie Farmer, Student, DIY, Angler, Gay and lesbian,Retired, main shoppers,tourists etc

Term.Name: GEOGRAPHICAL
GÉOGRAPHIQUE
Term.Definition: The territory for which the programme is primarily intended..

Term.Name: Universal
Universel
Term.Definition: Intended for all audiences regardless of territory

Term.Name: Continental
Continental
Term.Definition: Asia, European

Term.Name: National
National
Term.Definition: France, S Africa

Term.Name: Regional
Régional
Term.Definition: Mid West, Pacific Rim

Term.Name: Local
Local
Term.Definition: Zip Codes, Postcodes, Towns, specific local group

Term.Name: Multinational
International
Term.Definition: more than one country but not continental

Term.Name: International
Multinational
Term.Definition: more than one country but not continental

Term.Name: LANGUAGE OF TARGET AUDIENCE
Term.Definition: As used and maintained by ISO 639-1

Term.Name: ORIGINATION
ORIGINE / MODE DE PRODUCTION
Term.Definition: Made originally for viewing in the cinema

Term.Name: Cinema
Cinéma
Term.Definition: Made originally for viewing in the cinema

Term.Name: TV
Télévision
Term.Definition: Made originally for viewing on TV screens

Term.Name: Made on location
Réalisé en extérieur
Term.Definition: made at an event in an unstructured environment - where the action is based

Term.Name: Made in studio
Réalisé en studio
Term.Definition: made in a puropse built studio or controlled environment such as quiz show from village hall where the action comes to the equipment required to make the programme

Term.Name: Radio
Term.Definition: Made originally for listening on Radio

Term.Name: Made on location
Réalisé en extérieur
Term.Definition: made at an event in an unstructured environment - where the action is based

Term.Name: Made in studio
Réalisé en studio
Term.Definition: made in a puropse built studio or controlled environment such as quiz show from village hall where the action comes to the equipment required to make the programme

Term.Name: Online distribution
Distribution en ligne
Term.Definition: Made originally for distribution over non broadcast networks (streaming or download)

Term.Name: Made on location
Réalisé en extérieur
Term.Definition: made at an event in an unstructured environment - where the action is based

Term.Name: Made in studio
Réalisé en studio
Term.Definition: made in a puropse built studio or controlled environment

Term.Name: Off-line Distribution
Distribution en différé
Term.Definition: CDs DVDs, other removable media
